<details>

<summary>üß™ Laboratory Experiments</summary>

Best used under controlled conditions for reproducible results.

</details>

<details>

<summary>üå± Greenhouse Experiments</summary>

Ideal for experiments where environmental uniformity is crucial.

</details>

<details>

<summary>üêÑ Animal Feeding Trials</summary>

Works well when animals are homogeneous in age, breed, or weight.

</details>

<details>

<summary>ü™¥ Pot Experiments</summary>

Suitable for experiments with uniform soil and environmental factors.

</details>

# Advantages & Disadvantages of CRD

::: columns
::: {.column width="48%"}
::: {.callout-tip icon="false"}
## Advantages

‚Ä¢ Simple to design and analyze\
‚Ä¢ Flexible in number of treatments and replications\
‚Ä¢ Maximum degrees of freedom for error term\
‚Ä¢ Missing data doesn't complicate analysis significantly\
‚Ä¢ Easy to understand and implement\
:::
:::

::: {.column width="48%"}
::: {.callout-warning icon="false"}
## Disadvantages

‚Ä¢ Requires homogeneous experimental conditions\
‚Ä¢ Less precise than blocking designs when heterogeneity exists\
‚Ä¢ Can lead to larger experimental error if conditions are not uniform\

:::
:::
:::

# CRD Linear Model

The mathematical form of the **Completely Randomised Design (CRD)** is very important because it gives a precise, structured way to describe and analyze the experiment statistically. This helps us understand that what we observe is not just random - it‚Äôs a combination of systematic treatment differences and random variation.

The **CRD linear model** allows us to partition the total variation in the data into:

 - Variation due to treatments

 - Variation due to random error
 
**The model assumes**: Errors are independent, normally distributed, and have equal variance. These assumptions make it possible to apply valid statistical tests, confidence intervals, and predictive models.

::: {.callout-tip icon="false"}
## **CRD Linear Model**
</h2>

<p style="font-size:1.5rem; text-align:center; color:#004d40;">

<strong>Y<sub>ij</sub> = Œº + œÑ<sub>i</sub> + Œµ<sub>ij</sub></strong>

</p>
:::

<ul style="font-size:1.1rem; line-height:1.8; color:#004d40;">

<li><strong>Y<sub>ij</sub></strong> = observation for the <em>jth</em> unit receiving the <em>i</em>th treatment</li>

<li><strong>Œº</strong> = overall mean</li>

<li><strong>œÑ<sub>i</sub></strong> = effect of the <em>i</em>th treatment</li>

<li><strong>Œµ<sub>ij</sub></strong> = random error (assumed \~ N(0, œÉ¬≤))</li>

<li><strong>i</strong> = 1, 2, ..., t (number of treatments)</li>

<li><strong>j</strong> = 1, 2, ..., r (number of replications)</li>

</ul>

</p>

::: callout-tip
#### Without the mathematical model, we couldn‚Äôt formally test or compare treatments reliably.
:::

# ANOVA Table for Completely Randomized Design (CRD)

| **Source of Variation** | **Degrees of Freedom (df)** | **Sum of Squares (SS)** | **Mean Square (MS)** | **F Ratio** |
|:------------------------:|:---------------------------:|:-----------------------:|:--------------------:|:------------:|
| Treatments               | \( t - 1 \)                | SST                     | MST                  |\(\dfrac{MST}{MSE} \)|
| Error (Residual)         | \( N - t \)                | SSE                     | MSE                  |              |
| Total                    | \( N - 1 \)                | TSS                     |                      |              |
